Problem 2.1

Gee Whiz Everyone Wins Game: Finding Theoretical Probabilities

In the last five minutes of the Gee Whiz Everyone Wins! game show, several members of the audience are called to the stage. Each person chooses a block at random from a bucket containing an unknown number of red, yellow, and blue blocks. Each block has the same size and shape.

The contestants cannot see the blocks. Before choosing, the contestants predict the color of the block they will draw. If the prediction is correct, the contestant wins. After each selection, the block is put back into the bucket and the bucket is shaken.

What do you think random means?

Initial Challenge

Your class decides to play the Gee Whiz Everyone Wins! game. You and your classmates will take turns. You will try to predict the color of the block you select from the container.

Make a Prediction

  • Which color do you think will mostly likely occur?
Students might think that each color is equally likely. Some students may realize that there is no way to predict without more information â€“ it would just be a guess.

Conduct the Experiment

Equipment

  • Opaque container such as bucket, box, or bag
  • Various numbers of three different colored blocks (e.g., red, yellow, and blue) of the same size. The amount of each is only known by someone leading the experiment, such as your teacher.

Directions (with the whole class or in large group)

  1. Assign a leader to run the experiment. This person
  • makes sure that no one looks in the container,
  • holds the container near the player taking a turn,
  • allows the player to select a block,
  • puts the block back into the container,
  • stirs or shakes the blocks in the container, and
  • gives the next player a turn.

Everyone else is considered a player.

  • Take turns one at a time.
  • Predict the color of the block you will select from the container.
  • Without looking in the container, draw a block out.
  • Does the color match your prediction? If this was a game, you would win.
  • Record the color of the block.
  • Return the block to the container.
  • Repeat with the next player.

Analyze the Data: Experimental Probability

  • Based on the data collected during the game, what is the experimental probability of choosing a red block? Blue block? Yellow block?
Answers will vary depending on the data collected.
• Would you rather be the first player or the last player? Explain.
The person to choose last from the bucket has the advantage because he or she has more information about what is in the bucket.
• Does it matter that the block is returned to the bucket and the bucket is shaken after each contestant? Explain.

Yes.

Shaking the bucket helps to keep the outcomes random.

Returning the block makes the probability the same for each player.

Analyze the Data: Theoretical Probabilities

  • Examine the blocks in the bucket. What is the theoretical probability of drawing a red block? Blue block? Yellow block?

Based on 9 red, 6 yellow, and 3 blue blocks:

P(Red): 9/18 or 1/2 of the blocks

P(Yellow): 6/18 or 1/3 of the blocks

P(Blue): 3/18 or 1/6 of the blocks
• Are the outcomes of red, blue, and yellow equally likely? Explain why or why not.

Each color does not have the same chance of being chosen because the number of blocks is different for each color. There are more red blocks than there are yellow or blue blocks, so choosing the color red is more likely than choosing yellow or blue. Choosing blue is least likely.
• How does theoretical probability compare to the experimental probability?
Answers will vary.
• What is the probability of drawing a green block?
P(green) = 0/18 or 0
• What is the probability of not drawing a red block?
P(not red) = 9/18
• What is the sum of the theoretical probabilities of drawing each color block?
The sum of the theoretical probabilities is 1. 9/(18 )+ 6/18+ 3/18= 18/18=1
